docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is considering a requirement that all over-the-counter drugs include a warning against their discretionary use by pregnant women, according to Dr. James M. Bilstad, acting director of the agency's Office of New Drug Evaluation. ''No drug has been proven 100 percent safe for the unborn and we can't say there is no risk,'' he said. ''Some risks are so small we can't detect them in laboratory or clinical trials.'' The agency has not determined the wording for the warning or set a date when it might appear on labels, he added.

headline.main: F.D.A. MAY WARN ON DRUGS IN PREGNANCY

byline.original: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists at Rockefeller University said yesterday that they were able to ''turn on'' and ''turn off'' the symptoms of depression in rats by injecting specific substances into a key center deep inside the brain. The scientists believe the experiments represent an advance toward understanding the basis of depression in humans and in developing strategies to control it. Symptoms of depression in rats are similar to those in humans. They include poor performance on tests of motor activity, sleeplessness, loss of appetite, loss of aggressiveness and an absence of play activities.

headline.main: DEPLETION OF HORMONE LINKED TO DEPRESSION
